values:
Morville & Rosenfeld07, chapters 1, 2

In these two chapters, the author discusses the various aspects of effective web design.  In doing so, he also discusses what the annoying parts of web design can be, such as flashing and spinning GIFs, in addition to frames and slow-loading pictures.

In the last decade, web design has come quite a way from what it use to be.  Most people have learned what makes a site effective and have done so by having the experience of visiting an annoying site that contains irrelevant images or is difficult to navigate.

The information architect's job is defined by the list below.  They are responsible for making a browsing experience as simple and non-confusing as possible.

Information Architect's job:
  • Clarifies the mission and vision for the site, balancing the needs of its sponsoring organization and the needs of its audiences.

  • Determines what content and functionality the site will contain.

  • Specifies how users will find information in the site by defining its organization, navigation, labeling, and searching systems.

  • Maps out how the site will accommodate change and growth over time.
It is essential for the IA to consider what is important to the consumer.  This of course varies by target audience and purpose of each individual website and company.  It is important for the IA to step back and consider the needs of the learner and what is trying to be achieved by the website.

As a producer it is then necessary to think about what steps can be made that are both beneficial and cost-effective for both sides of the interaction.  It is important to think about the production from both the insider's and outsider's perspective.

In reading these chapters, it made me evaluate the website that I have created over the past, and how they have changed in time to include things that I thought were useful tools to a website, and to not include the mouse-trailers, spinning gifs, and other items that were 'hip' back in the mid-90s in website design.

Moreno, R., & Mayer, R. E. (2000). Engaging students in active learning: The case for personalized multimedia messages. Journal of Educational Psychology, 92, 4, 724-733.
Steuer, J. (1995). Defining visual reality: Dimensions determining telepresence. In F. Biocca and M. R. Levy (Eds.), Communication in the age of virtual reality (pp. 33-56). Hilldale, N.J.: Lawrence Erlbaum.
The Moreno & Mayer article deals with the interesting topic of whether including an individual's name (or personal messages in general) engage the learner more than impersonal lessons.  In a recent class trip, we visited with the ESI Design Company, founded by Edwin Schlossberg, a interaction designer known for creating personal experiences.  I have visited his creation at Sony Wonder, NYC where visitors input their name and picture onto a digital card, and at the end of the experience have their name and picture (with a list of all their completed activities) printed on a certificate. 

Steur discusses how virtual/visual reality has changed the way that people can experience things.  Telepresence refers to using experiencing something through a medium, and differs from the original and unique experience by this.   I actually think I referenced an article written in 2000 that also deals in telepresence, for my paper on Second Life.  I think many virtual realities can seriously effect and change the way people experience and view things.  In some cases, I think even the culture of emailing could be considered as a form of telepresence experiences. 

It is interesting to consider how real-world reactions to a virtual experience can enhance the experience and make it more vivid.  In certain video games (including internet ones), being hit can cause the joystick or controller to vibrate in response.  I believe that this definitely heightens your sense and warns you of the impending danger.  Similarily, (I think) the wii controllers can also vibrate to make you more response.

 

The connection between these two pieces is that some sort of personal interaction with you (the human) can cause a more meaningful or vivid experience.  I think this is what all interactivity designers are (or should be) designing towards.

Saffer, D. (2007) Designing for Interaction. Berkeley: New Riders. [chapters 4, 5]

Wittrock, M.C. (1992). Generative learning processes of the brain. Educational Psychologist, 27(4), 531-541.

Betrancourt, M. (2005). The animation and interactivity principles in multimedia learning. In Mayer (ed.), The Cambridge handbook of multimedia learning, pp.287 -296. New York: Cambridge.

Wittrock's piece discusses how learning can occur at a more superior level if the knowledge is being generated by the learner themselves.  By providing learners with the authentic experience of learning through exploration and research, rather than being told simple facts, achieve a deeper level of processing.  In the experiment with sixth grade English classes, reading comprehension was double that of the control group. 

The Betrancourt article further supports engaged learning perspective with a discussion of the importance of animation and interaction.  It further describes the scenarios in which animation can increase the learning through visual highlighting of important texts for beginning learners to differentiate between important and irrelevant pieces. 


Saffer provides a great and in depth view of interaction design which acts as an overview on the discussion of interaction, engaged learning and knowledge building.

Tidwell, J. (2006). Designing Interfaces. Cambridge, MA: O'Reilly. [ Read Overview / About Patterns | Review Patterns for Showing Complex Data and Making it Look Good ]

Alexander, Ch. (1977). A Pattern Language. New York: Oxford. [ Introduction ]

Saffer, D. (2007) Designing for Interaction. Berkeley: New Riders. [chapter 6]

Peirce, C. (1894). What is a sign? (Peirce Edition Project)


Tidwell's article talks about patterns in designing an environment.  When designing an environment using a system that user are unfamiliar with, it is necessary to follow the rules of the tools.  In a website, users know that there should be a general code or form by which they can navigate through a website, ie, on a restaurant's website, they know to look in "About Us" to find the location of the restaurant, if a "Location" tab is absent.  These are pattern-components which are already available prior to the creation of a website.  Additionally, rules are creates by the designer of the site.  Usability is defined by the decisions of the designers, and patterns are created to provide users with a easily navigated experience.

Alexander's piece highlights the patterns prevalent in language, and how a project can be influenced by the choice of language used, even in the organizational segment.  The character of an object within a project can depend incredibly on the language used to describe it.  Importance is given through a lengthier discussion, larger or longer words, and more attention to fine detail.  Without telling the reader expressively, the writer can represent the importance to textual patterns.


Pierce's piece discusses the ways we think about things, when they are presented to us in voluntary and involuntary formats.  When something is involuntarily or forcibly presented to us, there is an initial reaction which has no bias as to like or dislike, as it will always be present.  Second comes the choice of presence, either we want more of it, or want it to lessen/stop.  There is a thought which is the third step, which governs how we go about stop or continuing the experience. 


"There are three kinds of interest we may take in a thing. First, we may have a primary interest in it for itself. Second, we may have a secondary interest in it, on account of its reactions with other things. Third, we may have a mediatory interest in it, in so far as it conveys to a mind an idea about a thing. In so far as it does this, it is a sign, or representation."

The three kinds of "signs" are likeliness, indication, or symbols.  All objects can be represented or rerepresented, and it is a matter of how this is all done.


Poor signage.

For this entry, I have decided to change the format of my blogging style.  Given the opportunity to view the entries of my classmates, I believe that I should attempt to have a similar conversation about the articles in reference to one another, not as separate pieces.  I will however say that it is probably more familiar to me to blog in my previous style, so I am unsure how consistently I will blog in this conversation-between-articles style, or for how long.

That being said, I think it is extremely important for designers to think about the emotional responses of their users.  In many cases, as pointed out in Sharp's piece, much of the focus is spent on the technical issues of a interactive piece of software and how the user will perceive (not respond to) a learning scenario.  While a tactile response, such as the selection of a letter in a quiz is important, the message which the users receives in response to their selection is just as important, if not even more important that the actual selection.

I think Astleitner's article on EDI (Emotional Design of Instruction) is an important piece in determining and outlining the emotions which should be considered during the design process, and how they must meet 4 criterion to be considered. 

"Types of feelings are considered, which (a) are included in theoretical dimensional approaches for studying emotions, which (b) do not need long-term supportive treatment programs, which (c) are important in the social
context of school or instruction, and which (d) are not covered by cognitive or motivational design approaches."

Additionally the "F(ear)E(nvy)A(nger)S(ympathy)P(leasure)-approach for designing positive feeling instruction" is also an important and interesting thing ot consider as a designer.  Tying together Sharp and Astleitner, it is essential to think about the user, the responses they receive and their perceptions of the interface and interactive.  Frustration, as paired with fear of being unable to act farther, can affect a learner's capabilities, just as in Sharp's piece 'gimmicks' and extraneous parts of a product can get in the way of learning.  Design decisions should be made with the user's emotional response in mind: reducing fear, envy and anger, and increasing sympathy and pleasure, which is further broken down into four parts: physio-, socio-, psycho-, and ideo- (cognitive) pleasures.

The entries that precede (above) this post are from a new semester. Fall 2007.

They will be for my course "Representation and Interaction Design for Education" taught by Jan Plass and Ruth Schwartz.

The image of my avatar is very quickly 'maturing'. My little girl is growing up, lol.

In the world of SecondLife, there are many things to do. Some start businesses, others work for them, and still yet, others flock to what's been build because of attractions such as lottery balls or camping chairs.

I have been on Second Life for about 2 months now. Second Life is a social world in which, based on constructivist theories, you build your experience around you. What you learn is what you make of the world. As my self in Real Life is one addicted to accessorizing and buying new clothes, I find that my SL character is taking on a similar role, besides sharing a similar name. I almost wish I had taken screen captures of my character to show how she's been changing over the weeks, as I've learned how to buy new outfits and customize them to the body shape of my avatar (otherwise, you can pick up a cool looking hair piece, only to find that your skull protrudes out in the back). I really enjoy the editing, and I've started creating (building) a few of my own. Today I spent some time creating the perfect nose ring, in an attempt to match mine in real life.

I'm sure there is all this social psychology which goes behind how people create their avatars, and what their avatars look like compared to the real person. As of late, it has become normal for people to request a RL photo. SL gives the opportunity for users to upload their own pictures and put RL photos in their profile (this of course costs L$L$L$). Its still an interesting occurrence, as I thought part of SL was the fantasy of talking to people you didn't really know anything about.

In addition to my game diary, I am working on creating an architecture module within Second Life.
Robert, Mikhail, and I will be teaching people how to build within SL, starting with basic prims, and moving into topics such as how to group objects together so they can then be manipulated together.


Thus far, I have spent some time analyzing the architecture present in Second Life. In contrast to our real lives, architecture in SL has fewer constraints. Gravity is a big one, and use of materials and geometric constructions has less of an importance. People generally just build as they go, not necessarily planning what a building will look like, but based on conversations with folks in SL, they generally just have a mental picture of what they want it to look like. Because there is no purchasing of materials, such a whimsical view of building can be afforded.

Here are a few screen captures I've taken of varying building types in SL.


Example 1

Example 2

Example 3

Example 4
An interesting read... Wallace, P, Psychology of the Internet (2001)

Here's another educational potential within SL, that is totally up my alley. Last year I taught a digital photography course to kids, and I love this idea.

In SL, you have the opportunity to send postcards over email for free. You can take a picture and send it to anyone (including yourself) via email. The only thing is that you have to actually put in an email rather than user-to-user.

If you're teaching photography through SL, you can talk about cropping and zooming in and out, in addition to panning with the camera. SL allows to you to pan, and actually take pictures from angles that you might normally not be able to get into. Also, another math aspect, all of SL is in coordinates allowing you to type in coordinates to teleport to a spot.

And you know everyone is into self-takes these days.

Pea, R. (1999). New Media Communications Forums for Improving Education research and Practice. In E. C. Lagemann & L. S. Shulman (Eds.), Issues in Education Research: Problems and possibilities (pp. 336-370). San Francis.


A great article which includes parts about the educational aspects of virtual worlds.

http://counterbuzz.com/tui/

Here's something I never thought I'd find on SL... its a tutorial site, similiar to what we'd like to create/ design to exist within SL.

I love the mentors of SL! They're extremely helpful...

http://rpgstats.com/wiki/index.php?title=Main_Page

http://www.lslwiki.com

Apparently there is also a official SL site which teaches scripting.

I forgot to mention that I was presented with a different body shape (one more appropriate for females) and a smoother skin for my avatar. On "Orientation Island" or "Help Island" there are mentors who have been hired by the makers of SecondLife, to look out for and teach newbies. There is a currency on SecondLife known as Lindens, which is named after the creator. Anyone with the last name Linden is an official representative of the company, whilst mentors are being compensated in some small amount my the company (or so they claim its a low amount). Anyway, SecondLife seems to be a place where people just want to help each other.

It seems the main goal of SecondLife is to built, create, and possibly sell or trade goods. After going through some tutorials, this was the first object I made. Putting together two rectangular prisms and two toruses, this is my preliminary couch. (I ended up making it a lovely zebra print, but I didn't capture that in the picture.) You can add textures to objects, and also add "scripts" to objects, such as rotation or hovering. Furthermore, you can add features such as softness or gravity to an object. Its a lot of fun playing with the setting of the objects.

This is my first game diary blog entry.

For my project for a course on Educational Video Games, I've decided to chronicle my experiences in a game called SecondLife.

I joined SecondLife about a week ago, and was surprised at the complexity of every aspect of the game. Players are allowed to customize their avatars from outfits and accessories, to eye color, amount of freckles, breast buoyancy (something I can't say I've ever really thought about), amount of forehead showing, and the likes.

When I entered SecondLife, I was dropped into an area on "Orientation Island" where all the newbies were editing their appearances, so I likewise did the same. It was a little difficult, as the graphics for the faces are a little lower in resolution. After this, there was a path to follow, which was littered every so often with a floating green hand icon to click on. Each hand explained a different feature of SecondLife, such as shouting, flying, moving objects, etc. As I made my way towards the center of the island, I got to practice these things.
